column60:
When fixing bugs, finding the bug and fixing it in the debugger is great. I have worked on projects (one was a major shipping company using Gemstone) where the official waterfall method was: (1) identify the problem, (2) submit a document with the proposed fix, (3) after approval make the changes, (4) test. In reality we did the following: (1) used the debugger to identify the problem, made the code change, and tested it, and saved the classes with the changes, (2) submitted the document with the proposed fix, (3) applied/merged the changes into the system.

Another time a on a corporate website re-branding project, the UX developer commented about CSS that one can change it without recompiling. Then he thought for a second and said, 'You Smalltalk guys can do that with everything.' He was envious.

I am currently researching some complex ideas in Gemstone and I have been able to use Gt4Gemstone and the Glamour browser to make it much easier to understand the object structure through the Glamour inspector and extending the Glamour class browser. To me these are invaluable tools to help manage the complexity of objects.
column61: I have not done a lot of this. I have generally used screenshots, and shared bits of code or Applications within Envy. This is useful but to have a truly live development environment where both are working on same code would be interesting. It could be helpful but I am not certain how helpful. I would have to think more about the use cases.

column60:
Being spoiled by Squeak/Morphic, I find it tedious to inspect objects in "more professional" interfaces such as in VASmalltalk. Halos and "implementors of [a menu item]" feel much more immediate than "inspect focused widget [after x sec countdown]". Still, this is better than in Java applications...

One example where live programming is somewhat hampered in Squeak is developing interfaces with the ToolBuilder. When you change the code that builds the tool (e. g., event or action selectors, layout), you have to close and reopen existing instances of the tool to see the changes (because it does not get rebuilt just because the build code changed, obviously). I would appreciate if the feedback cycle were more immediate there.

I miss the debugging (and programming in the debugger) experience every time I do not work in Smalltalk.
column61: Sometimes I wish that Squeak would interact/integrate better with the OS/Desktop. For example, accept more drag-and-drop objects (than files) under Windows or be able to drag objects out of the Smalltalk environment into other applications. Dragging an object or a stack trace from Smalltalk to the e-mail client, Gmail or a GitHub issue might be cool...

column60:
VW Smalltalk is one of most powerful IDE available. All development tools are written in Smalltalk itself and all of the source code is available for examination. Smalltalk is encouraging the exploratory style of programming.  
Manuy of the modern programming things like Agile, Pair Programming, OO have their roots in Smalltalk.
column61: VW Smalltalk has support for most common electronic communication protocols HTTP(s), FTP, Imap, SMTP, etc.

column60:
Being able to lively share the SAME workspace/playground I'm using with a fellow worker would be a plus. So we both can work on the code or inspect the objects reachable.
Also, being able to restart the VM from whitin the VM, I don't know if that is possible, but for a live running system, being able say "shutdown, but restart afterwards" would give us a last resort to restart a live system.

column60:
We should continue to use pharo method doc (>>>) and add example in the method comments.
We should continue to have <sampleInstance> because this is super handy and we should have a lot more examples.

The primary goal of test is not documentation it is regression identification. 

We should also push the ide to keep track of problems (like the ghost work of Eric Tanter so that we can go over the compilation mistakes and check them later).
